## Large Language Models in a nutshell {.smaller}

> LLM are pre trained models that predict the next word based on input.

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

* **Where Do They Learn From?**
  * Books. Wikipedia, Websites, Online articles (Stuff people publicly wrote online â€” before a certain date.)
* **What Does â€œTrainingâ€ Mean?**
  * The model reads billions of sentences to learn how people write and speak â€” spotting patterns, not understanding like a human.
  
:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

* **What Can They Do?**
  * Answer questions; Write emails, stories, and summaries; Translate languages; Help with coding
* **But Be Aware:**
  * They might make things up; they donâ€™t "know" facts â€” they guess based on patterns, they are not search engines, but can search the web.

:::

## Strategy for teachers

> You don't have to use it!

* September-October: Explore, donâ€™t rely on it for education
* October-January: If you want to use in Semester 2, start preparing with our team
    * [TLC-FMG AI consultancy](https://tlc.uva.nl/en/article/ai-consultancy/)
* February: Use in education

::: {.notes}
Sharon
5 minutes stop at 16:20
:::

## Availability for Students

> UvA AI Chat will also be available to students starting September 1. The focus and essence is on exploring and experimenting with these new possibilities. Lecturers remain in control of how education is designed and whether UvA AI Chat will be used or not.

Jessica and Sharon

:::: {.columns}

BUT - Elephant In The Room - Fraud

* Check Your Essay Prompt
* Add parameters that are hard for AI to do [use resources from class; cite 10 resources that are peer-reviewed journals]
* Find Different Ways of Supervising (can you somehow see the process?)
* Add Presentation
* Talk with your students
